data: Three joining fragments of marble plaque: the two fragments on the right were set in plaster in modern times.
Quadrate Ε, square lunate Σ, cursive Ω. Two Christograms with the letters A and Σ at start and end of inscription and a dove holding a twig below.
4th century CE or first half of 5th century CE
Found in 1740 “in via qua ad suburbium itur' (Amico)
I.Sicily with the permission of the Assessorato Regionale dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana - Dipartimento dei Beni Culturali e dell’Identità Siciliana
Castello Ursino, Piazza Federico II di Svevia, 95121 Catania (CT)
Association pour l’encouragement des études greques, « Bulletin épigraphique », Revue des études grecques, 1888, http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/797735566
C. Wessel, Inscriptiones Graecae Christianae Veteres Occidentis, Inscriptiones Christianae Italiae (Bari: Edipuglia, 1989)
Antonio Ferrua, «Osservazioni sulle iscrizioni cristiane catanesi», Bollettino Storico Catanese 3 (1938): 60–74
Marta Fogagnolo revised the text encoding, added dimensions, italian translation and commentary

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text based on photographs;
  • line.1: Amico, Torremuzza, Ferrara, Wessel: Δ ((chi-rho)) Σ (i.e. δ(οῦλο)ς Χ(ριστοῦ)); Kaibel: Α ((chi-rho)) Ω; Korhonen: A ((chi-rho)) Σ
  • line.5: ΝΙΙ lapis
  • line.7: Amico, Torremuzza, Ferrara, Wessel, Korhonen: Α ((chi-rho)) Σ; Kaibel: Α ((chi-rho)) Ω

English translation

Alex Antoniou

Here lies Kekilianos, having lived for 20 years. Peace for all of you in god.

Italian translation

Marta Fogagnolo

Qui giace Kekilianos, avendo vissuto 20 anni. Pace a tutti voi in Dio.

commentary

This Christian epitaph presents the traditional formula with ἔνθαδε κεῖται (here in the phonetic spelling κῖτε) and the name of the deceased with the indication of his age through the participle ζήσας. It follows a wish for peace that is very often found in the inscriptions of Sicily and Catania in particular (see Ferrua 1938: 68): for other examples from Catania see IG 14.540 = ISic001359 and IG 14.543a = ISic003701. The name Κεκιλιανὸς (Καικιλιανός) seems to be attested only in this inscription in Sicily (more frequent is Καικιλίος), but the female form Καικιλία is attested in its phonetic spelling in another inscription of the 3rd-4th cent. CE from Catania (IG 14.2406 = ISic001361). The reading of the Christograms is debated: Kaibel read the apocalyptic signs Α ((chi-rho)) Ω, Amico, Torremuzza, Ferrara and Wessel interpreted the first Christogram as Δ ((chi-rho)) Σ (i.e. δ(οῦλο)ς Χ(ριστοῦ)), but a careful reading of the stone reveals that the correct interpretation is Α ((chi-rho)) Σ. Manganaro (1964: 295) misinterpreted the dove’s tail in fr.B as a 'planta pedis' (i.e. a footprint), in the absence of fr. A.

marble plaque

Overall dimensions:

20 21.5 2.5 chiselled

Quadrate Ε, square lunate Σ, cursive Ω. Two Christograms with the letters A and Σ at start and end of inscription and a dove holding a twig below.

Lines 1-8 15-19 Interlineation line 1 to 2 not recorded Catina Catania 37.49223, 15.07041 4th century CE or first half of 5th century CE Found in 1740 “in via qua ad suburbium itur' (Amico)

Dimensions of frA:

20 19 2.5 Observed by Amico and Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino superiore (formerly sala VI, 104), Collezione Biscari. None

Dimensions of frB:

18.5 14 2.5 A bird with a twig in its mouth is depicted at the foot of the inscription. Observed by Amico and Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino del cortile, collezione Biscari. None

Text based on photographs Amico, Torremuzza, Ferrara, Wessel: Δ ((chi-rho)) Σ (i.e. δ(οῦλο)ς Χ(ριστοῦ)); Kaibel: Α ((chi-rho)) Ω; Korhonen: A ((chi-rho)) Σ ΝΙΙ lapis Amico, Torremuzza, Ferrara, Wessel, Korhonen: Α ((chi-rho)) Σ; Kaibel: Α ((chi-rho)) Ω

Here lies Kekilianos, having lived for 20 years. Peace for all of you in god.

Qui giace Kekilianos, avendo vissuto 20 anni. Pace a tutti voi in Dio.

This Christian epitaph presents the traditional formula with ἔνθαδε κεῖται (here in the phonetic spelling κῖτε) and the name of the deceased with the indication of his age through the participle ζήσας. It follows a wish for peace that is very often found in the inscriptions of Sicily and Catania in particular (see Ferrua 1938: 68): for other examples from Catania see IG 14.540 = ISic001359 and IG 14.543a = ISic003701. The name Κεκιλιανὸς (Καικιλιανός) seems to be attested only in this inscription in Sicily (more frequent is Καικιλίος), but the female form Καικιλία is attested in its phonetic spelling in another inscription of the 3rd-4th cent. CE from Catania (IG 14.2406 = ISic001361). The reading of the Christograms is debated: Kaibel read the apocalyptic signs Α ((chi-rho)) Ω, Amico, Torremuzza, Ferrara and Wessel interpreted the first Christogram as Δ ((chi-rho)) Σ (i.e. δ(οῦλο)ς Χ(ριστοῦ)), but a careful reading of the stone reveals that the correct interpretation is Α ((chi-rho)) Σ. Manganaro (1964: 295) misinterpreted the dove’s tail in fr.B as a 'planta pedis' (i.e. a footprint), in the absence of fr. A.
